Award.AwardTitle: Support for US Participants at CIRM, March 13-17, 2017 Conference: Scattering, Resonances and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop "Resonances: Geometric Scattering and Dynamics," taking place at the Centre International de Recontres Math√©matiques (CIRM) in Luminy, France, from March 13 to 17, will gather researchers working on the different aspects of the geometric theory of resonances (spectral geometry, representation theory, harmonic analysis, microlocal analysis, analytic number theory, mathematical physics, microlocal analysis, quantum dynamics, geometric scattering theory) as well as Ph. D. students and junior researchers from different countries. Its objectives are to present and discuss the latest results on the geometric aspects and dynamics of resonances, share points of view and ideas, and to strengthen or promote interactions. The conference will give Ph.D. students and young scientists the opportunity to meet some of the prominent researchers in the fields related to resonances and to exchange ideas with them. To make the more specialized talks accessible to the participants, some experts will give tutorial and survey talks. Moreover, two afternoons will be devoted to talks of junior participants. This will give the Ph.D. students and the postdocs the possibility of presenting their work, which is an essential step for entering in the world of research and for building scientific collaborations.

The notion of resonance was introduced in quantum mechanics to study metastable states of a system, that is long-lived states from which the system deviates only with sufficiently strong disturbances. Mathematically, resonances appear either as discrete eigenvalues of the quantization of a classical Hamiltonian or as the eigenvalues of the transfer operator of the classical flow. Their study, initially aimed at Schroedinger operators on R^n, was extended to more geometric situations. Because of the role they play in various physical contexts there has been a considerable progress in understanding the geometry and the analysis of classical and quantum resonances in the last years. Nevertheless, many important and basic questions are still open. Many difficulties preventing to use classical arguments arise because of the non-self-adjoint nature of resonances. Also, in the geometric case of (locally) symmetric spaces, very little is known when the rank of the spaces is bigger than 1. Partial advances have been obtained, with several different approaches, using either harmonic analysis and representation theory, or microlocal analysis and techniques from scattering theory such as complex scaling. To study resonances in higher dimensional and higher rank geometric situations, a joint effort of different mathematical communities is therefore needed, and young researchers should have contacts with experts from the various aspects of the theory to make significant progress. POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop ``Resonances: Geometric Scattering and Dynamics",

took place at the CIRM, Luminy, France, from March 13 to 17. It gathered

top researchers working on the different aspects of the geometric

theory of resonances (spectral geometry, representation theory,

harmonic analysis, microlocal analysis, analytic number theory,

mathematical physics) as well as Ph. D. students and young

researchers from different countries. They presented

and discussed the latest results on the geometric aspects and

dynamics of resonances and shared points of view and ideas.

 

It gave the Ph.D. students and young scientists the opportunity

to meet some of the main actors in the fields related to resonances

and to discuss with them and gave the Ph.D. students and the

postdocs the possibility of presenting their work, which is an

essential step for entering in the world of research and for building

scientific collaborations. Two afternoons were devoted to talks by

young participants only.

 

The notion of resonance was introduced in quantum mechanics to

study metastable states of a system, that is long-lived states from

which the system deviates only with sufficiently strong

disturbances. Mathematically, resonances appear either as

discrete eigenvalues of the quantization of a classical Hamiltonian

or as the eigenvalues of the transfer operator of the classical flow.

Their study, initially aimed at Schr\"odinger operators on the Euclidean space, was

extended to more geometric situations.

 

Hyperbolic manifolds provide an interesting geometrical context for

the study of resonances. Counting

properties of the resonances reflect geometrical properties of the

geodesics on the manifolds and play an important role in several

applications in the theory of dynamical systems and in number

theory. For general hyperbolic manifolds, analogues of the above

results, when available, are much more delicate. They are

nowadays the object of intensive studies, by means of different

techniques and viewpoints (Baladi, Bortwick, Datchev, Dyatlov,

Faure, Guillarmou, Hislop, Liverani, Mazzeo, Nonnenmacher,

Olbrich, Perry, Vasy, Weich, Zworski…).

 

Because of the role they play in various physical contexts

(evolution of propagation of states with certain regularity properties

or decay at infinity, trace formulas, relations between classical and

quantum dynamics), in the last years, there has been a

considerable progress in understanding the geometry and the

analysis of classical and quantum resonances. Nevertheless,

many important and basic questions are still open. Many

difficulties preventing to use classical arguments arise because of

the non-self-adjoint nature of resonances. Also, in the geometric

case of (locally) symmetric spaces, very little is known when the

rank of the spaces is bigger than 1. Partial advances have been

obtained, with several different approaches, using either harmonic

analysis and representation theory, or microlocal analysis and

techniques from scattering theory such as complex scaling. To

study resonances in higher dimensional and higher rank geometric

situations, a joint effort of different mathematical communities is

therefore needed, and young researchers should have contacts

with experts from the various aspects of the theory to make

significant progress.

 

Bringing together researchers from different countries at an early

stage of their career evidently opens their minds to international

cooperations as well as to the idea of taking up positions in the

partner organizations. Experience shows that these early stage

encounters are the base of future personal networks which in

turn are the basis of institutional networks.
